episode.title: Klehr v. A. O. Smith Corporation

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Number 96-663, Marvin Klehr v. A. O. Smith Corporation.
Mr. Bird.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The last predicate, criminal last predicate act rule of accrual is the most appropriate rule for civil racketeering claims for three reasons.
First, it takes account of the unique elements of this cause of action.
Secondly, it is consistent with the congressional objectives and underlying policies of the law.
Third, it greatly reduces the administrative and judicial burden and the economic burden upon the parties because of its ease of application.
Selection of a rule of accrual in RICO must first of all take account of the sui generis nature of this cause of action and its unique pattern element.
In a garden variety tort case, say a car accident, for example, all of the elements are present at the beginning.
This explains the normal, or traditional rule of accrual.
In a RICO case this is not true, because the injury must arise out of a pattern of racketeering activity, and the pattern itself must also be perpetrated by a RICO enterprise.
These--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, you're assuming... when you say that all of the elements don't have to be present at the beginning, you're assuming that if I am injured by the first of three predicate acts I have suffered a RICO injury, aren't you?

I mean, I agree if I'm injured by the second of three predicate acts I have suffered a RICO injury, but we've never held that the person who is injured by the first of what later becomes a series of predicate acts has suffered a RICO injury, have we?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well... no, this Court has not held that.
However, I think an analysis of what a pattern of racketeering is would help in answering that question.

If you want me to go on I will, but my understanding of a pattern of racketeering activity is that it is simply a definition that can only be determined in retrospect, such that even two predicate acts, for example, don't necessarily constitute a pattern.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But if the injury precedes the pattern it's rather hard to say that it was a RICO injury.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Well, the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And I'm not sure that that's necessary in your case.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --No, it's not necessary in our case, but let me--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It is necessary to the theory of statute of limitations you're pressing upon us, however.

The argument you were just making assumes that, assumes that the first injury constitutes a RICO injury even though at that time there's no pattern and you have not been injured, when you're injured, by a pattern of racketeering activity.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --If I may explain, the way I view the structure of the statute and the definition itself, it assumes already in place, and the only way by definition that we can conclude that a pattern exists is that we have a beginning and that we have an end.
It can only be decided whether or not it exists in retrospect.

Once we determine that it exists, then that first predicate act is just as much a part of the pattern as the last predicate act, and that's our contention here, and that's why trying to determine when a RICO pattern along this continuum which Congress has defined somehow is borne or springs to life, if you will, under the H.J. Inc. rule of continuity plus relationship, that's an extremely difficult thing for anybody to follow, and certainly difficult for a--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That still leaves the metaphysical question, or maybe the legal question of why there can be a RICO injury before there's a RICO in existence.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --The... it is a metaphysical question, I grant you, but the way the Congress has defined pattern of racketeering activity and the way this Court has interpreted it, it can only be decided whether or not it existed in the past, and what the framework of your question is, that somehow we need to be able to identify it in prospect, and it can't be done, and that's the point.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I don't see it that way myself.
The normal default rule for when a statute of limitations begins to run is that it runs from when the cause of action accrues, when it exists, right?
That's the normal rule.
Once all the elements of the cause of action exists, then the statute of limitations period begins to run.
That's the normal rule, right?
Will you concede that?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Well, I would not concede that, because in Havens Realty this Court has indicated that where we have a continuing tort the proper rule of accrual can be from the last predicate act.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, it could be, but the normal rule as I understand it is that the statute of limitations will begin to run as of the time the cause of action comes into existence, and under RICO, it doesn't come into existence until all the elements are present, injury, predicate acts, and pattern.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: In--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And as of that moment, then, it could start to run, the statute of limitations, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, I have two answers to that.

First of all I think the normal rule of accrual, at least in present day law, is a discovery rule, discovery of the elements, or certainly discovery of the injury, and that rule is modified to require--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I think some courts have applied such a rule.
I would not say that that is the normal rule for accrual of causes of action and running of statute of limitation.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, that may be, and... I guess I've forgotten what the original question was, if you could restate it, please.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, as applied to your case I don't see why the statute wouldn't begin to run once you can say all the elements of the RICO cause of action are in existence.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: All right, and if I may get to that, I think what this Court has said, for example, in Havens Realty is, if we have a continuing violation the concerns that we typically have for a statute of limitations such as repose and staleness, they fade away.

What we have here is a congressional objective as stated by this Court in Turkette, Russello, and a number of other cases, which recognizes that long-term pattern felonious conduct is a bane on our economy.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, this statute is patterned after the antitrust law, the Sherman Act, and that also can involve a continuing stream of conduct by the violator, and what rule have we applied there for statute of limitations?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: I understand that, but I think applying... adopting the statute of limitations--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What rule have we applied there, do you think?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --As I understand it, the antitrust rule is... runs from the date of injury.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Yes, so... and if this action, RICO is patterned after that, why shouldn't it be the same?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Because the rule of accrual is different than the statute of limitations, and I think that the rule of accrual that the Court selects must take account of the elements, and one of the unique elements of RICO is pattern, and that's not... that doesn't exist in the antitrust laws.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Bird, as I understand it the principal difference between your case and others is the principal problem that you have is the identification of the source, and in Clayton Act cases generally it's known who it is, but here, it isn't a question of injury or pattern, it's a question of, you didn't know the source, and that's why I found your argument rather puzzling.

It seemed to me the Eighth Circuit test, which was injury and source, discovery of injury and source plus pattern was the rule, and that your disagreement really was about the identification of the source, because if those three elements are there, then on... as I understand your claim, you would be within the statute.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Yes, we would.

We are... we claim that under whatever rule this Court selects we think we're within it, but the fact remains that the Klehrs were not able to identify the source of their injury, and they did everything within their power.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And that's the whole thing of your case is they knew they were hurt, and then they knew that there had been all this advertising, but they didn't connect the pattern with the source of the injuries.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: That's correct.
They did not connect the pattern with the source of the injury.

But there is a larger question here should the Court choose to address it, and that is, why should this Court or Congress be interested at all in granting repose to a criminal enterprise that's engaged in a long-term continuous pattern of felonious activity?

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, of course, that assumes the question.
Part of the statute of limitations design is so that people that are not guilty of being in a criminal activity have the evidence that's fresh to rebut your allegation.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: And that is true, but if... if... let's assume that the RICO plaintiff is able to establish that and meets the pattern element, which is a strict element that this Court has imposed under the H.J. case, two acts are not necessarily enough.

We need continuity plus relationship, and if we assume, for example, a 30-year pattern and somebody suing on the act that takes place in the first year and he can pass that hurdle of identifying a pattern, which under most circuits needs to be pled, then what's happened is we have a 30-year pattern of criminal felonious conduct that nobody's stepped up to the plate to stop, and I think in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I wouldn't have that problem if I wouldn't allow the first suit, right?
You're back to that issue again, whether the first person has a RICO cause of action.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --And--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'll give you 10 years, not 30.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, of course, the definition--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That is the distance between the first predicate act and the second, so the person who is injured 10 years later after the first one clearly has a RICO cause of action, and the first predicate act occurred 10 years ago.
That's the outside time of it, isn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --What I... of course, I tried to address that, and what I'm saying is that once we are able to identify the pattern, that is... and understand what I'm saying here is that being able to identify a pattern is only a matter of perception, and that means that we have a judge or an attorney or a RICO plaintiff saying, I'm looking back in time, and what is... what can I perceive from what's gone on in the past, and that implies, of course, discovery.
You're in possession of facts from which you should conclude--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It seems to me your clients were incredibly obtuse not to have discovered this.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, I disagree with that.

I disagree with that, and I certainly think a fact question exists, and the mere fact that the silo may not have met their economic expectations does not necessarily cause them to question the underlying concept that... of oxygen limiting, which was the basis for the sale here.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Bird, I agree that all of the elements have to have been in existence, as Justice O'Connor suggested, but why do you think all of the elements have to be known, including the existence of the pattern?
Let's take, you know, a garden variety tort action for a physical injury to someone.
Suppose the physical injury occurs.
Doesn't the statute begins to run immediately?
And let's assume the injury was intentional so that the individual could sue for assault, but he didn't know it was intentional at the time.
He just thought it was negligent.
Now, he later finds out, 3 years later, that it was in fact intentional.
Does he have a longer statute of limitations for assault than he would have had for negligence, assuming the jurisdiction has the same--

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --the same 2-year statute for both?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's his problem.

Indeed, he didn't know that it was intentional, and that made it a higher species of tort, just as the... a series of RICO violations makes this a higher species of tort, but that's too bad, so once he learned of the injury he should have sued.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: I agree with your hypothetical that that wouldn't extend the statute of limitations, but here it's within his power to make that investigation and to find out.
What we're dealing with here, and this is... we have a whole new way of attacking a problem, and I'm suggesting that we can't get by with using what's termed the traditional rules.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but even on the traditional rule, isn't it your position also that because one of the elements is fraud, and because fraud at least will normally be accorded a discovery rule, that therefore you have until the point of reasonable discovery, even under the traditional rule, or a traditional analysis, without regard to the peculiarity of RICO itself.
Isn't that your position?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Well, I think part of our position... that is part of our position, but understand, the rule we're advocating, which is the criminal last predicate act--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Oh, I quite realize that, but if you take the hypothetical that Justice Scalia gave you, and you substitute for the intentional versus negligent act a fraudulent act, I take it your position would be that even though so far as the element of failure to supply what they offered or any conventional tort, as to that the statute might run immediately.
Nonetheless, as to the fraudulent element I thought it was your position that the statute would not run until the moment of reasonable discovery.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --That is true, as... and that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So that you may very well lose the case conceptually by the adoption of a Clayton kind of analysis here, and yet if there were a traditional... if traditional treatment were given to the discovery aspect of the fraudulent element, you might still be in court.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You might still go back and have something to litigate.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Yes.
Your answer to that... the answer to that question is yes.

The RICO plaintiff under our analysis is put into a, sort of a classic catch 22, because all of the circuits are requiring significant pleading not only in terms of pattern but also identification of the underlying acts, and if you don't plead enough you're going to be out under Rule 9, and if you wait long enough so that you've got all the knowledge and crystallization that you need to be in order to satisfy this, the motivation of the defendant, RICO defendant is going to be to come in and say, well, we've been doing this for 50 years.
All of the elements existed a long time ago, and here's all the proof of it.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes, but he wouldn't... that wouldn't help if the injury was within the statutory period.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: That's true.
It would not help if the injury were in the statutory period, but the problem, or the catch 22 may get him beyond that time before he can understand that... and plead and prove the pattern element.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What is it... is it your view, then, the statute would run forever, there's no statute, or is it 13 years, or what is it?
I mean, you say the last act.
Well, all right, there's an act... separate out the problem of discovery, which I think is the same for any fraud, so imagine everybody knows everything.
Now, I'm hurt yesterday.
All right, now do I go back for 1,000 years?
I mean, this was the last act.
It turns out that every 5 years they committed one act since 1940.
Do I go back to 1940?
Is that your idea?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Let's assume... your hypothetical necessarily assumes that since 1940 the RICO enterprise has been engaged in--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, one act every 5 years.
That's what they do.
It's a bank, and what they've done is they've told one lie or one fraud in a loan application every 5 years.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Right, and--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And it's the same person, and he's done it year after year, so what do we do under your theory?
I'm just trying to find out whether there's no statute of limitations in effect, or--

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --whether it's... there's none, right?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Yes.
The answer is that the statute runs from the time of the last predicate act, and the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
Now, why is it the case that in RICO there should be effectively no statute of limitations, but with price-fixing there is a statute of limitation?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, there is a statute of limitations, and it's 4 years.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, but I mean... and if I have a price-fixing case I take it that if they've been engaged in fixing the prices of their electrical conduits for 30 years and I've been hurt, I can go back only... is it 3, or is it... 3, I think.

All right, so why would it, if we're copying the Clayton Act, where you have a price-fixing case you only can go back 3 years, but if it's RICO you can go back a million years, or let's be honest about it.
You go back 15, 20, whatever.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Right, and the answer to that question is that the congressional intent, as stated in the preamble and also is recognized by this Court, is in part under Turkette to divest the enterprise of all its ill-gotten gains.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
In price-fixing we don't like that particularly.

I mean, I take it this Court, when it decided to adopt the Clayton Act as the model, looked at the congressional intent and thought that the congressional intent is best served by copying the Clayton Act.
Now, is there something you could point to specifically that would say in this aspect we shouldn't copy the Clayton Act, though in others we should?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Yes, and I think it's the congressional policies and objectives that are contained in the structure of the statute itself, as well as the policies underlying the law.

And if... the structure of the statute shows no concern for the twin issues of repose and staleness and, indeed, a RICO plaintiff is required to prove past injuries well... that are well in the past, and a RICO defendant is required to defend those, not only the injuries but the predicate acts themselves.
What would be the policy justification for not allowing... for allowing a RICO defendant to get out of divesting themselves of the older ill-gotten gains?
Any other rule would permit the RICO defendant to want to continue, because as long as he--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That argument was raised in Malley-Duff.
I mean, I raised it, in fact.
You know, I... in a dissent I said there shouldn't be a statute of limitations for RICO.
You either use the State statute or use none at all in this case.
That was rejected, however.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --I understand that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We have adopted a 4-year statute.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: You have.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Surely it has to have some meaning.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Yes, it does.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And it has no meaning if in Justice Breyer's hypo the thing can be rejuvenated every 5 years, every time there's a new predicate act.
Even though the 4-year statute has already passed since the last predicate act, as soon as there's a new predicate act 1 year later the whole thing comes to life again.
That's not a statute of limitations of any sort that I ever heard of.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: What... the policy advanced there is that if you adopt a rule of accrual, once the defendant makes up his own mind that I'm going to stop this criminal activity he knows that 4 years later his liability's over.
If he's foolish enough in year 5--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Unless he changes his mind 5 years later, right?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Then if he's foolish enough to do what you just said, which I think is a little bit unlikely, but let's assume that it takes place, why shouldn't we get him for it?
Why should he be able to get away with it?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What other statute of limitations works that way, where the statute has run and then someone does something again and somehow it's all... the statute has ceased running.
I mean, ordinarily you would have, if there's a 4-year statute of limitations and I libel you or I do something, it's... the 4 years expires.
If I libel you again, it's a new cause of action, a new... but you can't resurrect the old libel.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Well, I differ with that.
I think that again in Havens Realty the Court just... did just--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, Havens was an unusual case.
The Court acknowledged as much, didn't it?
I suspect it's not likely to be repeated.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, okay.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Bird, I continue to be troubled by the abstract quality of your discussion, because here it wasn't every 5 years.
It was constant.
There was this sales pitch going on constantly.
So let me ask you this question.
Suppose a veterinarian had come to the Klehrs' farm in 1978 and said, you know what causing your cattle to sicken?
It's that silo.
How much time would you have to sue?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Under the last predicate act rule we would still be timely, and I think that that's... there are a myriad of reasons why a person who suffers some type of injury might not sue at the beginning.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What was the last predicate act?
You're saying that there is a new predicate act every time the person who has committed a fraud denies that he's committed a fraud--

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: No.
That--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --and tells the seller, that's a perfectly good silo?
Is that a new fraud?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --That's a new predicate act, but--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why is it a new predicate act?
The seller has the $64 thou.
It's in his pocket.
He's not getting any more money.
Why is there a new fraud?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Well, I think he is getting more money from the overall marketing scheme and strategy.
There is money being generated not only by the dealer franchise fees but also by way of sales of repairs on the project, sales of collateral--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Sales to other people.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --And repairs to the Klehrs themselves.
There were repairs within the statutory period, for example, to the silo, that they were motivated to continue to use, operate, and maintain the silo.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They charged for these repairs?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Certainly.
The dealer charged--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They made a profit on it, do you think?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Pardon me?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They made a profit on these repairs?
Do we know that?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: I don't think... I don't think there's anything in the record that says they made a profit.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I'm concerned with... your brief makes this point both for extending the RICO statute and also for asserting that even if we don't adopt your position as to the last predicate act there was in fact a new and separate injury when these later... when these later--

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --representations were made, a new accrual, in other words.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Okay.
Let me address separate accruals.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes, I'd like you to do that.
That's what I--

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Of course, the circuits are really in a big state of confusion regarding this rule of accrual, and does it require separate and independent injury, or does it require a new predicate act, does it require both, and if so what is a separate and independent injury and what is a new predicate act?
I mean, the... if we're dealing with the separate and independent injury question... if I may, a very short hypothetical of my own.
Assume I own a nursing home and I buy a humidifier, and... the last 2 months of a 6-month period, and I only use it during the winter and the spring.
It creates a condition of molds because I don't have the right filter, and it spews toxins out and two of my patients die, and... who would say that those were not separate and independent injuries?
What we have here is a silo that when it's filled is filled with very good feed.

As the year goes by, and the silo starts to go down, starts to empty, the defect is such that it begins to create this cauldron, this witches brew underneath the dome which in the last months of operation starts to injure not only the new feed but also the different cattle that eat the feed.
And they don't all get the same disease.
They all get different types of diseases every year and different types of conditions and symptoms which are not identifiable.
Does that constitute separate and independent injury?
I believe it does, and it would meet the test of and surpass the test of Glessner v. Kenney that was the one case that discussed this, and Bingham v. Zault.

Now, do we have a separate predicate act, and I think we do, because under the RICO predicate acts that we're talking about, which is mail fraud, the mail fraud itself is any mailing in furtherance of a fraud, or any use of the interstate wires, and we certainly have that in the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --They don't have to obtain anything further?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Pardon?

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They don't have to obtain anything further?
Simply, in effect, an intentionally false statement through the mail, intended to conceal their--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In furtherance of a fraud.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: That would meet the requirements.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How is that in furtherance of a fraud?
The fraud has already occurred.
It's in the past.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: No, but it's still ongoing, and you have to--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You answered no.
I thought the answer was it was intended to conceal it.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --Oh, yes.
Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Is that enough on the mail fraud?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Well, it's a new predicate act that's part of the pattern.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, I just want the definition of mail fraud for the moment.
If they make the fraudulent representation through the mail for the purpose of concealing their prior fraud, does that satisfy all the elements of mail fraud?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: I believe it does, if the concealment itself is fraudulent.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And is it concealment simply to deny that the product sold earlier was defective?
That's a pretty lose definition of concealment.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: I don't--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: To keep on insisting no, that's a perfectly good silo, that is concealment?
I can understand if you say well, you know, they doctored reports about whether the cattle were sick or something like that.
That is concealment.
But just insisting that there's nothing wrong with the silo, that's concealment?

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: --I don't think in all circumstances it would, but I... there are some situations in which it would, and it would depend upon the circumstances under which that statement was made, and I would hate to have a rule that says that it couldn't be under any circumstances, and I agree with you that a construct could be made such that it would not constitute fraudulent concealment, and so... I don't know what else to say about that.
I would like to reserve, if I may.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, because it might not be fraudulent.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: It might not be fraudulent.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They could make that statement thinking they had a great silo out there, and that wouldn't be mail fraud.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: That's true, for the dealer, for example.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But if they knew the silo was bad, and a fortiori, if they knew at the time they sold it that in fact it would not do what they represented, then there would be a fraudulent concealment on your theory.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And the mail fraud would be the predicate act.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: I'd like to reserve, if I may.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Bird.
Mr. Ennis, we'll hear from you.

section.heading: Argument of Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The majority of the circuits have decided that the most appropriate accrual rule for civil RICO claims is the same discovery of injury rule that Federal courts use for civil claims in general.
That is a particularly sensible rule for civil RICO for three reasons.
First, the rule focuses on injury, which Congress made the distinguishing element of a civil RICO claim.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But Mr. Ennis, you have to have a cause of action in existence, don't you, under RICO?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: There has to be a pattern, and the predicate acts, and the injury.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So we're not talking about anything that starts before those things are present.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Not at all.
Under the basic rule that we are proposing, the cause of action accrues when all the elements of a civil RICO claim exist, whether the plaintiff knows all the elements or not.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Does that include injury?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: And the plaintiff has discovered injury.
That's the rule we propose, which is the basic discovery of injury rule.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: All right, now what if it involves fraud.
Do we apply the reasonably-should-have-discovered-the-fraud rule?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
That's the general rule for the discovery-of-injury rule.

All the circuits that have used the discovery-of-injury rule, and that's the majority, have interpreted that rule to mean that the cause of action accrues when all the elements exist and the plaintiff discovers or should reasonably have discovered his injury.

Discovery of injury is sufficient to induce a reasonably diligent plaintiff to investigate the cause of the injury and to determine all the elements needed to plead the claim within the 4-year period.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What do we do about the situation of additional mailing later on?
Is there a new cause of action, possibly?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, there are two aspects to your question, if I understand it correctly.

First, if you're asking, what if there's one act that injures the plaintiff but there's not a second or third predicate act constituting a pattern yet, I think that's not really a question of accrual.
That's a question, a substantive question of what constitutes a RICO claim.
The rule we propose would apply equally whichever way the Court resolves that question.

But the other part of your question touches on the doctrine of separate accrual, and there, too, we propose the traditional Federal rule of separate accrual which nine circuits have applied to civil RICO claims, and under that rule, as State Farm recognized and other courts recognized, the separate accrual rule means that when there are new separate and different injuries within the limitations period, that will start a new claim, a new cause of action.

That rule does not apply to this case, because both lower courts, viewing the facts in the light most favorable to petitioners, concluded that petitioners suffered no new injuries within 4 years of suit, in fact, no injuries within 6 years of suit--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr.--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --so the separate accrual rule does not help these petitioners.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Mr. Ennis, correct me if I'm wrong, but I thought that the rule was the discovery rule was injury plus source, not merely injury, and here, as I said to Mr. Bird, it seems to me the whole problem was not injury, was not pattern, but source.
These were farmers who knew they had a terrible problem, but they didn't know what caused it.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Ginsburg, to be as candid as I can, I think there's confusion in the lower courts on whether the discovery-of-injury rule means discovery of the injury or, as a few courts have said, discovery of the injury and the source of the injury, meaning who caused it.
The majority of the lower courts say the discovery-of-injury rule means discovery of injury.

I think that's... your opinion for the D.C. Circuit in Conners noted that point, and that should be sufficient to induce a reasonably diligent person to find out the source and all the other elements of the injury.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You don't need 4 years if you know both the injury and the source.
Presumably the 4 years is intended to give you time after you've discovered the injury to find the source.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Scalia--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Otherwise we could have a 1-month statute of limitations.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --I think that's completely correct, and is the reason why the other competing rule, the discovery-of-injury and discovery-of-pattern rule is not as appropriate for civil RICO as the rule we propose.

Once you have discovered both that you have been injured and by a pattern of racketeering activity, there's no reason to give you an additional 4 years after you know all that you know, need to know in order to file a claim.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: When you speak of the pattern of racketeering activity, are you speaking of a pattern of racketeering activity which includes, to your knowledge, fraud?
In other words, is the fraud element included in what you know when you say you have discovered a pattern?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: It could be, Justice Souter.
Of course, not all RICO actions involve fraud.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: They could involve arson, or embezzlement.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, when it does.
When it does.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: When it does.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: The discovery of a pattern is simply, as you're using the term, means discovery of the--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: It means discovery of the acts, which in law would constitute a fraud.

But there's another... your question raises another good reason to apply the general discovery-of-injury rule, because that rule has been found to be a fair and workable rule when applied in a very wide variety of circumstances to a wide variety of acts, and that makes real sense in civil RICO, given the enormous variety of acts that can constitute a pattern of racketeering activity.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Mr.... I'm not... I've never understood this fully, but I'm not certain that we have to go into... I'm not certain we have to go into the question of fraudulent... when you discover it and... what is it called, fraudulent concealment, but if we do, what is it you have to know?
I received the letter from the fake real estate company that says, Dear So-and-so, your investment is now worth nothing, because unfortunately there was bad conditions, all right?
So I know that.
I know the source.
Does it start to run?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe it would start to run.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, how does it work, for example, in price-fixing?
I go out and I buy a toothbrush, and the toothbrush cost $2.
All right, I'm injured.
It should have cost $1.
But I don't know anything about... and I know the source.
The source is the toothbrush company, all right.
Now, how... I have no... I don't investigate that kind of thing.
Nobody does.
And if you get a letter from your bank which says, we're very sorry, but your account is overch... you know, I mean, you don't investigate most frauds.
All you know is you're paying more money, or you're... so how does it work?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Breyer, that is the Clayton Act rule, the basic Clayton Act rule.
The cause of action accrues upon the occurrence of the injury even if the plaintiff has no knowledge that he has been injured.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, but there's a thing called fraudulent concealment which operates in order to prevent the very problem that I'm focusing on.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's a different doctrine.
Now, let me try to address that doctrine.
The doctrine of fraudulent concealment is not applicable in the circumstances of this case for two reasons.
All courts agree... all courts agree that the doctrine only applies when the defendant's acts actually conceal the elements of the claim.
There's a distinction between whether they can be self-concealing acts or affirmative acts that conceal, but all courts agree the defendant's acts must conceal the elements of the claim.
Here, both lower courts found, viewing the evidence most favorably to petitioners, defendants did not commit any acts which concealed the elements of the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So in other words, if I'm thinking conceptually, is this right, in cases like price-fixing or fraud, it starts to run from the moment that you discovery your injury, i.e., you wrote a bigger check.
Some courts say you also have to know the source.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Which isn't hard to know.
But then, if there is fraudulent concealment, as there often would be in price-fixing or fraud, that tolls the statute.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: If there is actual fraudulent concealment, which has two components, first that the defendant's acts actually concealed--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --the elements of the claim.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That was not this case.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Second, that's not this case for a second reason.

Both lower courts found, and in fact nine circuits, at least nine circuits agree, that even when the defendant's acts do actually conceal the elements of the claim, the plaintiff must nevertheless be diligent, and if a diligent plaintiff would nevertheless have discovered the elements of the claim despite the defendant's acts of fraudulent concealment, the doctrine of fraudulent concealment does not apply.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why do you say there's no actual concealment here?

Certainly one of the elements of fraud is that you knew that the product you sold was not going to do what you said it did, otherwise it's just negligence, and you're subject to breach of warranty, I suppose, but not to a fraud claim.
Now, didn't the seller here, A. O. Smith, indicate that it did... it believed that this silo was a properly working silo?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely, Justice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So why isn't that concealment of the element of knowledge that it wasn't a properly working silo?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --First of all, as Justice Kennedy's question earlier suggested, that question assumes that it is fraud, and that my client, A. O. Smith, knows that the silos won't work.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, of course it does.
When you get to the issue of whether there's concealment or not, you're assuming there was a fraud.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in this case the reason it doesn't conceal, even if you assume it's a fraud, is that the claims here are based on allegations that my client misrepresented the benefits of this silo.
B-2 of the appendix to the cert petition lists the alleged misrepresentations.

The lower courts found that long before, 6 years before they filed, petitioners should have known that all of the representations on which they claim to rely had not materialized, and there was nothing the defendants could do to conceal that reality.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're retreating to the second item that you raised in your response to Justice Breyer, namely that even where there is concealment--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --it does not excuse you if the--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --or it doesn't work to the plaintiff's advantage if a diligent plaintiff would have discovered it.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're saying a diligent plaintiff would have discovered it.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.
Maybe I didn't express myself as clearly as I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I didn't understand you.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --I'm trying to address the first part of your question.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Whether there's concealment.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: There's no concealment at all, because there is nothing the defendant did or could do that could conceal from the petitioners that the representations on which they relied were not materializing.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But that only goes to the contract description.

It doesn't go to the misrepresentation which is an element of the cause of action, and the fact that more than 6 years before they brought this suit they realized that the silo was not working as advertised does not support the proposition that they knew that Smith had misrepresented the silo's capacity.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Souter, they claim... if you look at B-2 of the appendix to the cert petition, they claim that the... the representations which they alleged were fraudulent included representations that this silo would make it possible for them to eliminate protein supplements.
They knew that never happened.
That... one of the misrepresentations was that they would be able to increase their milk production 3 to 5 pounds of milk per cow a day.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right, and when did they--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That never happened.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --When did they not merely know that those representations were proving to be untrue, but when did they also know that Smith knew they were untrue when they made them?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Justice Souter, no one ever knows for sure whether a defendant in a fraud case knows that claims are true or untrue until you've brought the trial and win or lose.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, it's a question of circumstantial evidence--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --like a great deal else.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And I think the only point that I'm making is, on the fraudulent concealment rule, it does not answer the fraudulent concealment rule issue to say they should have known that the silo was not living up to its description.
If the question is, when should they have known that the silo was also the subject of a fraudulent--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --description or representation.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, both lower courts, answering that second question, which was the second question in Justice Scalia's question, by concluding that doing the evidence most favorably for the petitioners they knew or should have known all of the elements of their RICO claim, including that this was fraud--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Ennis--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --if it was fraud, more than 6 years before--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --Explain that to me, because as a matter of fact, and I don't think this is disputed, these farmers consulted a veterinarian.
They had a nutritionist.
They wanted to know why their cattle were sick, and no one tipped them off to a possible relationship between the sickness of the cattle and the silo.
They knew the silo wasn't working, but they didn't know that that's what caused the sickness in the animals.
So they knew they had a problem.
They consulted people.
Why wasn't that diligent?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Your Honor, this case involves a lot of facts not all of which are in the cert petition or the appendix, but after reviewing all those facts, including the facts that the petitioners could simply have taken feed from the silo to be tested, which is a normal regular thing that most farmers do at least twice a year, which would have showed them that the feed from the silo either was good quality or bad quality... they didn't do that.

There were many things available to a reasonably diligent plaintiff whose milk production was going down for 19 years, whose protein supplements did not improve for 19 years, that they could have done to investigate and find out all the elements of their claim.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr.--
--If all that is correct... let's assume... I'm not sure that this happened.

Let's just assume that within 4 years of the time the action was filed a representative of the company came out and he looked at the feed with the farmer and he said, oh, that's that brown stuff, you want that, that's really good, knowing that that's not true, knowing that this is exactly what was hurting the cattle, would that have revived the cause of action?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.
It's the same answer, Your Honor.
It's the same thing as if they say this is a great silo.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Because if you should have discovered the fraud earlier, the fact that there are new acts of fraud are... is irrelevant?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Unless those new acts cause separate injuries within the limitations period.
These did not.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, suppose this continued to lull them into thinking there's nothing wrong with the silo and he lost 10 more cows?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, this case, both courts found... and those findings I don't think are properly before the Court, because although petitioner in their brief raises a question about whether the lower courts properly applied the summary judgment standard they did not raise that question in the petition for rehearing in the Eighth Circuit, in their cert petition, the questions presented--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But just... just with reference to my question, let's assume they came out within 4 years, said oh, this is great feed, knowing that it wasn't, and that 10 more cows were sick or died, and that the plaintiff was lulled into believing that the silo was okay.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --That would simply be a continuation of the damages that flowed from the initial fraudulent act if it was fraudulent, inducing him to buy the silo.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why isn't that a repeated injury?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it's not a new injury.
It's not a new, different, and separate injury, Your Honor.
That's the... that's a critical point in the separate accrual doctrine.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So in Justice Breyer's case, where a bank is defrauding people on credit cards, if you should have found out 15 years ago but they keep doing it you can't sue for the last 4 years, or for the period within the statute of limitations since the new acts have occurred?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.
That's the general--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But I thought you said you could recover for the 10 more cows, assuming that it's a new misrepresentation.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --If it's a new misrepresentation--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, so--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --within 4 years--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --Right.
Yes, you can recover for that.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --which causes injury--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --within 4 years you could.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So with the bank, you can... with the bank--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --if the bank keeps doing it, you recover you just go back 4 years at a time.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's not this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But fraudulent concealment, you don't necessarily need a new injury.
That can toll the statute of limitations, can't it?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Fraudulent concealment can toll, if there are affirmative acts that actually conceal, if there are acts that actually conceal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And the second question presented is whether respondent's fraudulent self-concealing conduct, acts of fraudulent concealment, suspend the statute of limitations, so at least that portion of the fraud claim is presented in the petition for certiorari.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: We don't dispute that the fraudulent concealment issue is presented.
We do dispute that any question about whether the lower courts properly applied the summary judgment standard is presented.
Let me just make--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you... may I ask you question kind of going back to the beginning for a minute?

I just want to know what your view is... it's perhaps a substantive question rather than a tolling question, but assume that they sold three silos, each of which was defective and they knew they were defective within the 5-year period, and the first purchaser is the first predicate act altogether, does he have a cause of action?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Again, Justice Stevens, I think that's a substantive question of RICO--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Right.
What's your view of the substantive question?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --It's different from the accrual rule.
Personally, I think that the first person injured by an act, the first predicate act which later turns out to be a pattern, would have a civil RICO claim once the pattern emerges.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Even though there had--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: But that's my personal belief.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Even though there had been no violation of RICO at the time--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: At that point.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --of his injury.
It's retroactively created?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, and I reach that conclusion because this is a remedial statute, and Congress understood that some of the patterns could take as much as 10 years.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is there any parallel doctrine for that, or is that unique to RICO?
It's just strange to me that a RICO injury happens, and then the RICO pattern is completed later.
I just find that very odd.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: It is odd, Justice Kennedy, and I don't know of any parallel, and I don't know what lower courts would say in answer to that question.
Let me make--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's so odd that I'm inclined, if you really believe that, to think that the 4-year statute of limitations should be interpreted with similar oddity.
[Laughter]
What good is a 4-year statute of limitations if you don't know for even 10 years until--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Let me--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --whether you have... before you have a cause of action.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --let me just... let me just note--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Extraordinary.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --I'm sure it's clear, but that question is not raised by the facts of this case, because the pattern quite clearly existed well before the purchase of the silo in 1974.
They allege there were at least 20 acts of mail fraud on which they relied before 1974.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I understand that, but I'm quite serious that my view of the statute of limitations has to depend to some extent upon my view of what RICO does, and if there is in every case a 10-year, I don't know, limbo period--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No, that wouldn't be true.
The fact that the pattern might not emerge for 10 years would not mean you could not have a pattern of acts some of which are every 2 or 3 years apart that go on for 20 or 30 years.
That's a separate question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --No, but your view would permit the conclusion that the statute of limitations would run before the statute was violated.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.
No, Justice Stevens.
I... if that's the answer you... I didn't mean to suggest that at all.
The statute of limitations would only begin to run when there was discovery of injury and all the elements of a RICO claim were in existence.
Now, the Court may answer that in existence question one way or the other.
Our rule would apply whichever way the Court answered that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That would mean that if you had a victim of the first predicate act and then three more predicate acts that occur over a 5 or 6-year period, the statute, the cause of action would accrue at the end of the 6 years.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, Justice Stevens.
That's correct.
Now--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Ennis, there's one more piece of this about the discovery of the source.

There was the continuing sales pitch, but there was also, it was alleged, was it not, that the company had done testing on its own, and that testing showed that the silo was not performing as advertised, and yet no one who had purchased this silo was told, your cattle may sicken and even die.
Isn't that relevant to the discovery of the source?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, there are two things I'd like to say about that, Justice Ginsburg.
First, that's not what those internal studies show.
This company has sold 83,000 of these silos.
There have been 270 claims.
3/10ths of 1 percent have experienced problems.
That's not what the internal studies show.

But even if they did show that, that would not qualify as fraudulent concealment under the fraudulent concealment doctrine that almost all circuits apply, because those acts would do nothing to prevent the petitioners from discovering the elements of their claim.
The elements of their claim are, the representations on which they relied proved to be false.
Their cows were not doing well.
They were injured, and there was a pattern of activity.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Known to be false by the seller.
You have to add that.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, you can add that, Justice Scalia, if you--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You must add that for fraud.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --You have to be able to allege that, that's correct.
It has to be able to plead--

turn.speaker: clarence_thomas
turn.label: Justice Clarence Thomas
turn.text: --prove it at the time.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Now, let me... I've not got to the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but again if--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --central point--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --I'd like to make, if I could, about why the criminal RICO rule, which is the only rule the petitioners urge, Justice Souter.
They do not urge a discovery rule at all.
If you look at their motion for a divided... response to the motion for a divided argument that's crystal clear.
It's also clear on pages 20 and 21 of their brief.
They don't urge a discovery rule.

The critical problem with the criminal last act rule, like the civil last predicate act rule, is that it would enable a fully knowledgeable plaintiff who knows everything to delay filing for many, many years.

It is not tied to the injury component of civil RICO, because the last violation under the criminal rule, or the last predicate act under the civil rule, don't have to have injured the plaintiff at all.
They don't have to have injured anyone at all.

Now, that makes no sense to use that rule, which is adrift from concepts of injury, in civil RICO, where Congress itself determined that the gravamen of a civil RICO claim is injury and a specific kind of injury, injury to the business or property of the plaintiff.
The fact that the last act might injure someone else is totally irrelevant to the plaintiff's civil RICO claim.
That's why any rule this Court adopts for civil RICO should be tied directly to injury.
Now, there are other reasons that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Although you acknowledge that it can be tied to an injury to somebody else if the injured plaintiff is the first one in the series of RICO acts.
In that situation, you don't insist on injury to this plaintiff.
You will wait 10 years to see if any other plaintiff is injured.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --Actually, the other plaintiff doesn't even have to be injured.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Doesn't even have to be--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: There can be a predicate act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Okay.
So to that extent you're willing to buy into the criminal rule.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Well, to that limited extent, Justice Scalia, but in the normal run of these cases, particularly where you're talking about an ongoing pattern of activity, the pattern would exist roughly at the same time as the first injury.
The second reason why the rule we propose makes more sense than later accruing rules is that it is more consistent with the private Attorney General function of civil RICO.
The point of the private Attorney General function, since the civil plaintiff can only recover his own damages and cannot punish the defendant for any injuries inflicted on others, is not financial.
It's to expose and deter ongoing patterns of racketeering activity--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Ennis--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: --before they injure others.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --You don't ask for the more strict rule of just, once the cause of action exists, that's it.
You start the statute running.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: The Clayton rule, Justice O'Connor?

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: We don't ask for it, but of course we'd be happy with it, since we would win under that rule.
This claim would have accrued in 1974, and it would be barred in 1978, but we don't urge the Clayton rule for two reasons.

One, the Clayton rule, although that's the basic Clayton rule, that occurrence-of-injury rule has not proved satisfactory even for all Clayton Act violations, which are much narrower in scope than RICO violations, so many Clayton courts have actually imposed different rules, and we think it makes sense to have a single rule for RICO that is broad enough to encompass all the acts that violate RICO.
Second, frankly, we think that the Clayton rule is a little harsher to plaintiffs than this remedial statute was probably intended to be.

We think that what Congress probably presumed, if it presumed anything at all, was that the general Federal accrual rule would apply, and that rule is discovery of injury, and we don't think that in the context of this statute there's anything in the text or purpose of RICO that would mean that Congress would have intended a harsher rule for civil RICO than the general Federal rule of accrual.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course, if Congress was reading our cases it would not have expected a Federal statute of limitations to apply at all, much--

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: If they'd read your dissent, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --We came to that later, didn't we?

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So I don't think it's very helpful to talk about what Congress intended.

turn.speaker: bruce_j_ennis_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bruce J. Ennis, Jr.
turn.text: No.
[Laughter]

No, but putting entirely aside congressional intent, in Federal courts it's judge-made law almost always to adopt accrual rules, but those rules are supposed to be consistent with and tied to the purpose of the underlying statute, regardless of what the congressional intent was, and for that reason we think since civil RICO the distinguishing element is injury, it should be discovery of injury that triggers the accrual.
Let me conclude by saying that the Havens Realty case, which has been mentioned here in argument, actually proves our point.

In Havens Realty... it wasn't a unique case, Justice Rehnquist, but in Havens Realty this Court rejected the continuing violations doctrine when applied to a claim that required proof of direct injury to the plaintiff, a misrepresentation claim.

It found the continuing violation doctrine not appropriate in that circumstance, only appropriate in the quite different circumstance of discriminatory practices which have indirect injury to the plaintiff even if they do not directly injure the plaintiff.
That is not this case.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Ennis.
Mr. Bird, you have about a minute remaining.

turn.speaker: charles_a_bird
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Bird
turn.text: A minute... oh.
Just two brief points.
Our case is not based on these misrepresentations of future benefits.
You can look at our complaint, which is probably 50, 60 pages long, and you won't find any of those allegations in there.
Our case is based upon the fraud relating to the oxygen-limiting nature of the silo.
Secondly, given the variables of farming, there is no way, and we have the expert affidavit in our proof from Dr. Olson.
It's on... if you would care to look at pages 168 through 170 of the joint appendix, it's fully explained in there.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Bird.
The case is submitted.
